item.description: Podcast Description The true story of little-known rooms in the New York City Board of Education building. Teachers are told to report there instead of their classrooms. No reason is usually given. Transcript

item.title: 349: Valentine’s Day 2008 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Veronica Chater’s mother wants to go to a resort in Mexico with a friend. Her father, a former cop with an extravagant sense of security, prepares as if she’s headed for a war zone. This, and other stories about couples, that happen decades after the moment their eyes meet. Transcript

item.title: 348: Tough Room | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description This week we bring you backstage with comedy writers at The Onion. They start with over 600 potential headlines for their fake-news newspaper each week, and over the course of two days, in the very tough room that is their editorial conference room, they select 16 to go in the paper. Plus other people speaking their minds in very tough rooms. Transcript

item.title: 347: Matchmakers | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Sabir, a young man in Afghanistan, thought he’d found true love but he couldn’t afford a wedding. So two foreign aid workers, friends of his, decide to come to his rescue. They soon find out making a lasting love match isn’t as simple as writing a check. Transcript

item.title: 346: Home Alone | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A 79-year-old woman, Mary Ann, dies in Los Angeles. She’s lived alone for decades. No one knows her—or her next of kin. There’s a body to be buried, a house full of stuff to get rid of. Transcript

item.title: 345: Ties That Bind | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A young girl named Sarah receives a heart transplant from a boy her age, and her mother sets off to find out more about the kid who saved her daughter’s life. But years later, Sarah’s not sure she wants to know. Transcript

item.title: 344: The Competition | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of the unintended consequences of market forces. Transcript

item.title: 343: Poultry Slam 2007 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For Thanksgiving, the time of year when poultry consumption is highest, it’s our annual program about turkeys, chickens, and fowl of all types. Transcript

item.title: 342: How to Rest in Peace | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description There are umpteen TV shows about solving murders, endless whodunits in bookstores. But what happens to the people left behind after the detectives close the case? Three stories about children trying to figure out how to live normally after their parents have died. Transcript

item.title: 341: How to Talk to Kids | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of adults taking very different approaches to communicating with children. Transcript

item.title: 340: The Devil in Me | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people trying to exorcize their inner demons. Transcript

item.title: 339: Break-Up | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Writer Starlee Kine on what makes the perfect break-up song and whether really sad music can actually make you feel better. Plus, an eight-year-old author of a book about divorce, and other stories from the heart of heartbreak. Transcript

item.title: 338: The Spokesman | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of what can happen when you go from being a private person to a public face. Transcript

item.title: 337: Man vs. History | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people taking history into their own hands. We hear from two men in two different wars. One is trying to make a difference in the current war in Iraq. The other is with the CIA at the very end of the Cold War. Transcript

item.title: 336: Who Can You Save? | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about the pitfalls of trying to do the right thing. Transcript

item.title: 335: Big Wide World | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description When he was a teenager, Haider worked in the Iraqi Ministry of Information. He was specially trained to talk to visiting dignitaries and foreign reporters, and he loved his job. It was exciting, and he was treated like a celebrity. Transcript

item.title: 334: Duty Calls | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Josh’s mother and younger brother were a mess. His mother drank too much. His brother got arrested a lot. Josh hadn’t lived with them since he was nine, and they didn’t play much of a role in his daily life—until duty called, and they took over his life. Josh told the sequel to this story at our live show in 2014. Transcript

item.title: 333: The Center for Lessons Learned | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Four years into the Iraq War, what have we learned? Soldiers, civilians, Iraqis, and Americans talk—and sometimes yell—about what they’ve learned in the last few years…including how to stay alive and why the aftermath of a war can be the trickiest time of all. Transcript

item.title: 332: The Ten Commandments | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people struggling to follow the Ten Commandments from the book of Exodus. Transcript

item.title: 331: Habeas Schmabeas (2007) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description An updated version of our episode “Habeas Schmabeas,” which won a 2006 Peabody Award. Listen to a special, uncut version. Transcript

item.title: 330: My Reputation | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people trying to recover from damage to their reputations—sometimes caused by others, sometimes self-inflicted. Transcript

item.title: 329: Nice Work If You Can Get It | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of sudden fame, quick riches, and the downside of the dream job. Transcript

item.title: 328: What I Learned from Television | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories recorded during our 2007 live tour. Sarah Vowell, David Rakoff, Dan Savage, and other favorite contributors went on the road with us to New York, Boston, Minneapolis, Chicago, Seattle, and Los Angeles; and performed brand-new stories in front of sold-out audiences. Transcript

item.title: 327: By Proxy | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of proxy fights, proxy arguments, and proxy situations of all kinds. Transcript

item.title: 326: Quiz Show | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A man with social anxiety goes through a transformation on a TV game show, a young woman with high ideals has them dashed by a TV game show, and teams compete to solve some of the hardest puzzles in the world, for fun. Transcript

item.title: 325: Houses of Ill Repute | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description An old man in Brooklyn invites some homeless prostitutes into his house on a cold winter night. They never leave. Plus other stories about houses, such as the United States Congress, where the inhabitants don’t always act as they should. Transcript

item.title: 324: My Brilliant Plan | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description An American reporter in Iraq decides to rent a house in a residential Baghdad neighborhood rather than live in a hotel and be an easy target for insurgents. And an eleven-year-old boy figures out an ingenious way to see his dead father again. Big ideas gone amok. Transcript

item.title: 323: The Super | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The mysterious hold supers have on their buildings, or that their buildings have on them. Transcript

item.title: 322: Shouting Across the Divide | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A Muslim woman persuades her husband that their family would be happier if they left the West Bank and moved to America. They do, and things are good…until September 11. After that, the elementary school their daughter goes to begins using a textbook that says Muslims want to kill Christians. Transcript

item.title: 321: Sink or Swim | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who are in over their heads and trying to stay afloat. Transcript

item.title: 320: What’s In A Number? — 2006 Edition | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Recently, the British medical journal The Lancet published an study which updated their estimate of the number of Iraqis who’ve died since the U.S. invasion. With that in mind, we revisit a show we did in 2005 about the earlier study published in Lancet estimating the number of Iraqi deaths. That study was mostly ignored in the U.S. Alex Blumberg revisits the original study and looks at the new one.

item.title: 319: And the Call Was Coming from the Basement | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For the lead up to Halloween, scary stories that are all true. Zombie raccoons, haunted houses—real haunted houses!—and things that go “EEEEK!!!” in the night. Plus, a story by David Sedaris in which he walks among the dead. Transcript

item.title: 318: With Great Power | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A family wishes for years that they could do something to stop their neighbor’s shocking behavior. Suddenly they get the power to decisively change things forever…and they have to decide whether they will. This, and other stories of everyday people who get saddled with great power—and the great sense of responsibility that goes with it. Transcript

item.title: 317: Unconditional Love | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Can love be taught? A family uses a controversial therapy to train their son to love them. And other stories about the hard and sometimes painful work of loving other people. Transcript

item.title: 316: The Cat Came Back | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description True stories that follow the plotline of the old kid’s song “The Cat Came Back.” It’s the simplest plot in the world: Something you thought was gone forever keeps returning, against all odds. Transcript

item.title: 315: The Parrot and the Potbellied Pig | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Original stories from David Sedaris, Jonathan Goldstein, and others, on two animals who don’t even seem like they should know each other, much less appear on the same radio show. Transcript

item.title: 314: It's Never Over | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A grown man tries to get to the bottom of why his schoolmates threw him in a lake 20 years earlier. And a woman buys a house on the cheap, with the understanding that the seller will soon vacate. Ten years later, she’s still waiting. Transcript

item.title: 313: Parental Guidance Suggested | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about kids who actually want their parents looking out for them. Transcript

item.title: 312: How We Talked Back Then | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In this show we return to two radio programs originally broadcast in 1996 and 1997. In one show, listeners came onstage with their letters, which they read aloud. In another, listeners from around the country talked about all the brand new sorts of experiences they were having with this new technology that had entered everyone’s lives, the Internet. Each show, in its way, is a kind of time capsule.

item.title: 311: A Better Mousetrap (2006) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people trying to find new solutions to age-old problems—solutions that sometimes cause problems of their own. Transcript

item.title: 310: Habeas Schmabeas | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The right of habeas corpus has been a part of our country’s legal tradition longer than we’ve actually been a country. It means that our government has to explain why it’s holding a person in custody. But now, the War on Terror has nixed many of the rules we used to think of as fundamental. At Guantanamo Bay, our government initially claimed that prisoners should not be covered by habeas—or even by the Geneva Conventions—because they’re the most fearsome enemies we have.

item.title: 309: Cat and Mouse | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about the kinds of chase games that just never end. From the high California desert to a high-end furniture showroom. Transcript

item.title: 308: Star-Crossed Love | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In honor of Valentine’s Day, This American Life brings you stories of how love blossoms, even when (perhaps) it shouldn’t. Transcript

item.title: 307: In the Shadow of the City (2006) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories that take place on the edge of civilization, just out of sight. Transcript

item.title: 306: Seemed Like A Good Idea at the Time | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A girl signs up for a class. A couple hires an accountant. A group of co-workers decides to pool their money and buy a couple of lottery tickets. In the beginning, they’re full of hope and optimism…and then something turns. Stories of good ideas gone bad. Transcript

item.title: 305: The This American Life Holiday Spectacular | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A full-throttle, show-stopping, no-holds-barred Christmas Spectacular! Shedding the crusty old Christmas stories of yore, we bring you new holiday classics. With special musical guest Marah! Transcript

item.title: 304: Heretics | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The story of Reverend Carlton Pearson, a rising star in the evangelical movement, who cast aside the idea of hell, and with it everything he’d worked for over his entire life. Transcript

item.title: 303: David and Goliath | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Variations on an old tale, with very modern consequences. Cambodia is competing with other nations for the business of big clothing companies all over the world…but they’ve vowed to follow fair labor practices. Other countries end up with the contracts, and the profits. Transcript

item.title: 302: Strangers in a Strange Land | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Someone once said, “If you’re not willing to be changed by a place, there’s no point in going.” This week, stories about what happens when you land in a whole new world. Transcript

item.title: 301: Settling the Score | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about the lengths we go to make things right, and about what money can and cannot fix. Transcript

item.title: 300: What’s In A Number? | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description About a year ago, a study estimated the number of Iraqi casualties since the war began at 100,000 dead—higher than any other estimate. The study was mostly ignored. Alex Blumberg revisits that study to look at the reality behind it. In Act One he reports that not only is the study probably accurate, but it says that most of the deaths were caused by coalition forces (despite concerted efforts to avoid civilian casualties).

item.title: 299: Back from the Dead | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people and places that have come back to life after everything seemed lost. Transcript

item.title: 298: Getting and Spending | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description How far will we go to get money? And once we’ve got it, what should we spend it on? The first half of this show is on making money, and the second half on spending it. Transcript

item.title: 297: This Is Not My Beautiful House | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description It’s the largest mass resettlement that America has seen since the Civil War, as over 400,000 people—victims of Hurricane Katrina—try to find a new place to live. From the Houston Astrodome to an abandoned New Orleans street, stories of people looking for home…and finding something else. Transcript

item.title: 296: After the Flood | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Surprising stories from survivors in New Orleans. We give people who were in the storm more time than daily news coverage can to tell their stories and talk about what they’re thinking. This leads to a number of ideas that haven’t made it into the regular news coverage. Transcript

item.title: 295: Not What I Signed Up For | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about being sucked into something against your will. In one story, a 9/11 widow finds herself having to comfort another distraught woman on national TV. And in a story by Nick Hornby, a boy is forced to play soccer to save his nation. Transcript

item.title: 294: Image Makers | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people and institutions who are worried about what the world thinks of them, and who take action…decisive action. Transcript

item.title: 293: A Little Bit of Knowledge | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about the pitfalls of knowing just a little bit too little. Transcript

item.title: 292: The Arms Trader (2005) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The U.S. government spent two years on a sting operation trapping an Indian man named Hemant Lakhani, whom they suspected of being an illegal arms dealer. It’s one of the few cases that has gone to trial in the War on Terror, and one the Justice Department has pointed to as one of their big successes. In the end, they got Lakhani, red-handed, delivering a missile to a terrorist in New Jersey.

item.title: 291: Reunited (And It Feels So Good) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about getting back together with your parent, your spouse, your … Brahman bull. And how it never goes the way you think it’s going to. Transcript

item.title: 290: Godless America | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description At a time when House Majority Leader Tom Delay calls for enacting a “Biblical world view” in government, when Christians are asserting their ideals in the selection of judges, in public school science classes and elsewhere, This American Life spends an hour trying to remember why anyone liked the separation of church and state in the first place. Transcript

item.title: 289: Go Ask Your Father | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Sons and daughters get to find out the one thing they’ve always wanted to know about their father. The answers aren’t always what they hope for. Transcript

item.title: 288: Not What I Meant | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about how easy it is for communication to go awry, and what the consequences can be after it does. Transcript

item.title: 287: Backed Into A Corner | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people who end up making choices they’d rather not make, when their options begin to run out. Sometimes this works out great; sometimes not so great. Transcript

item.title: 286: Mind Games (2005) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who try simple mind games on others, and then find themselves way in over their heads. Transcript

item.title: 285: Know Your Enemy | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about trying to understand who’s on your side. The defense minister of Israel visits would-be suicide bombers in prison, only to find out that in at least one case, he feels sorry for the terrorist. A prosecutor tries to censor a punk rock star. He takes him to court, but never bothers to listen to his lyrics. During the trial, he begins to think twice about his mission.

item.title: 284: Should I Stay or Should I Go? | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people teetering on the edge of this question: Should they stay or go? A software writer loses his job, but refuses to go away. He continues to show up at work, sneaking in the door each day and putting in long hours on a project the company canceled. A student from Pakistan finishes four years of college in Philadelphia and has to decide whether to move back home.

item.title: 283: Remember Me | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people who are remembered very differently than they’d wished. The ghost of a kindly, distinguished philanthropist supposedly plays pranks on guests at a Ramada hotel in Fond du Lac, Wisconsin. A dying mother makes a tape for her developmentally disabled daughter, hoping she’ll watch it someday, knowing she might not. Transcript

item.title: 282: DIY | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description After four lawyers fail to get an innocent man out of prison, his friend takes on the case himself. He becomes a do-it-yourself investigator. He learns to read court records, he tracks down hard-to-find witnesses, he gets the real murderer to come forward with his story. In the end, he’s able to accomplish all sorts of things the police and the professionals can’t. Transcript

item.title: 281: My Big Break | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Sometimes, getting your big break isn’t all it’s cracked up to be. A comedy duo lands the gig that can make them famous—the Ed Sullivan Show at the height of Sullivan’s popularity—and they bomb. A third-grader gets his big chance to please his mother and push his drunken father out of the picture. And other stories. Transcript

item.title: 280: In Country | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description What life is like for American soldiers in Iraq. Transcript

item.title: 279: Auto Show | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people who love their cars, for better or for worse. Transcript

item.title: 278: Spies Like Us | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about amateur spies—regular people who spy on other regular people, and the consequences of their spying. Transcript

item.title: 277: Apology | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description It’s rare that a successful apology happens. One where you apologize to someone, not for selfish reasons, but because you’re really sorry and you want them to know that, and when the person you’re apologizing to really hears what you’re saying. Three stories of people groping toward that moment. Transcript

item.title: 276: Swing Set | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A journey through the minds of undecided voters. For months—through the Swift Boat ads, the convention speeches, the debates—we tracked a few of these voters to find out why they just can’t make up their minds. Plus, a story of someone courting undecided voters, and another about people trying to sabotage undecided voters (and everyone else). Transcript

item.title: 275: Two Steps Back | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Ten years ago, when he was still a reporter for NPR’s All Things Considered, host Ira Glass did a year-long series on a Chicago public school where things were getting better. Test scores were rising. Students were motivated. Last year, changes at the school dismantled some of the programs that had made for the school’s success, and one of the best teachers in the school is thinking about quitting.

item.title: 274: Enemy Camp (2004) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Behind enemy lines, sometimes people get confused about whose side they’re on and how to fight the enemy. Transcript

item.title: 273: Put Your Heart In It | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people deciding whether to give it their all. There’s one story about a person who hasn’t, one story about someone who has—in a situation where success seems very unlikely—and one story about people who just can’t help themselves. Transcript

item.title: 272: Big Tent | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of the Republican Party, America’s new majority party. Yes, they’re still just barely the majority in the Senate…and in the last Presidential race…and in state legislatures around the country, where they hold just one percent more seats than Democrats nationwide. Transcript

item.title: 271: Best Interests | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about adults struggling to figure out what is in the best interest of some child. And in situations where, what is best is not so clear. Transcript

item.title: 270: Family Legend | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description How, one might wonder, could a simple hunk of cheese drive a wedge between an aging aunt and her devoted niece? Sure, every family has its share of grudges, secrets and bad behavior. What’s harder to understand is how those things end up changing family relationships in ways no one could have predicted. Three stories about family legends that have either been kicking around for years or been completely suppressed.

item.title: 269: Someone to Watch Over Me | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Letting someone else take care of you can change everything. Three stories of couples in which one partner is trying to take care of the other, sometimes with more resistance, sometimes with less. Transcript

item.title: 268: My Experimental Phase | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Three stories about people who decide to try out a new life—the kind of life their parents never wanted for them. Transcript

item.title: 267: Propriety | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Perhaps there was a time when the rules of polite society were clear. No longer. This week, we bring you stories of people forced to try to figure out how to maintain their dignity—and decency—in some very unsettling situations. Transcript

item.title: 266: I'm From the Private Sector and I'm Here to Help | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Today’s show is devoted to just one story. Contributing editor Nancy Updike went to Iraq to try to figure out what it’s like to be a private citizen working in the middle of a war zone. Private contractors are a part of this war in unprecedented numbers, but we don’t know that much about the people doing these jobs — why they chose to come to Iraq, and what they’re seeing that we can’t.

item.title: 265: Fake Science | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people trying to drag science where it doesn’t belong. Transcript

item.title: 264: Special Treatment | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We love it when we get it, but is it ever really fair? A defense of special treatment, by people who receive it and people who give it. Transcript

item.title: 263: Desperate Measures | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people stuck in unfixable situations who try desperate measures. Sometimes these are inventive, sometimes they’re ingenious, sometimes they even work. Transcript

item.title: 262: Miracle Cures | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description People looking for miracle cures, some from above, others from abroad. A son tries to help his mom in a faraway place defy the laws of medical science. A daughter tries to help her dad by going to a faraway place to defy the laws of the United States of America. Transcript

item.title: 261: The Sanctity of Marriage | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories trying to understand what actually happens in marriages during this time when the definition of marriage is up in the air. Music throughout the hour by a real wedding band, a good one: The Doug Lawrence Orchestra. Transcript

item.title: 260: The Facts Don’t Matter | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description There’s what happened, and there’s the story that gets told about what happened. Sometimes the two things don’t match up very well. This week, two case examples—ripped, as they say, from today’s headlines—of the story that’s told becoming the truth, even though the facts don’t back it up. Transcript

item.title: 259: Promised Land | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For millennia, people have tried to reach a spiritual promised land by fasting. Jesus did it. Buddha did it. Monks and saints and new age gurus have done it. And, for for this episode, the late David Rakoff tried it. He did a 20-day fast, to find out if it would bring him any form of enlightenment. Also, contributor Starlee Kine tells a story about getting as close to one promised land as you possibly can, without actually going in.

item.title: 258: Leaving the Fold (2004) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description People leaving the situation they’re used to and striking off for something less familiar. Transcript

item.title: 257: What I Should’ve Said | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description People return to the scene of the crime where they should have spoken clearly, plainly, forcefully…to review what the hell went wrong, and in a few cases, to fix it. Jonathan Goldstein tries to stop time. Charles Monroe tries to figure out how to teach a lesson to the President of the United States. Transcript

item.title: 256: Living Without (2004) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people living without. Nubar Alexanian explains what fish can do for him that his own ears cannot. Sarah Vowell explains the cheerful journalism of deprivation. And other stories. Transcript

item.title: 255: Our Holiday Gift-Giving Guide | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The vexing difficulty of finding the perfect gift. Transcript

item.title: 254: Teenage Embed, Part Two | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In early 2003, we brought you a special show about a California teenager, Hyder Akbar, who traveled to Afghanistan, his family’s homeland, for the first time. His father had moved back to work for Afghan President Hamid Karzai. Hyder brought along a tape recorder, and his audio diary, produced by Susan Burton, won the Silver Award for Best Documentary at the 2003 Third Coast International Audio Festival. Transcript

item.title: 253: The Middle of Nowhere | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories from faraway, hard-to-get-to places, where all rules are off, nefarious things happen because no one’s looking, and there’s no one to appeal to. Transcript

item.title: 252: Poultry Slam 2003 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description During the weeks between Thanksgiving and New Year’s - the highest turkey consumption period of the year - we bring you an annual This American Life tradition: stories of turkeys, chickens, geese, ducks, fowl of all kinds, real and imagined, and their mysterious hold over us. Transcript

item.title: 251: Brother’s Keeper | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Biblical fables ripped from today’s headlines. In his ongoing effort to write his own version of the Bible, Jonathan Goldstein retells the story of Cain and Abel. Finally we hear Cain’s side of the story. Plus: neighbors in a small town in Illinois wonder if they could have stepped in—as their neighbors’ keepers—to prevent a brutal triple murder. And the story of a man who lives his life among his political enemies, feeling responsible for the problems he believes they’re creating for everyone.

item.title: 250: The Annoying Gap Between Theory...and Practice | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Why is it always harder than you think it’ll be? We explore several case examples of the annoying gap between theory and practice. Transcript

item.title: 249: Garbage | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We make what’s usually invisible, visible: the world of trash. We follow the trash from the sanitation men on the street, to the mob guys who controlled the hauling business, to the people who actually live in dumps. Transcript

item.title: 248: Like It or Not | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Some stories we make happen, others happen to us. Extremes from the latter category, where people let things happen to them and don’t act, even when maybe they should. David Rakoff guest hosts. Transcript

item.title: 247: What Is This Thing? | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description What is this thing? This thing called love, that is. For answers, we explore the romance novel industry, a $1.5 billion empire run almost entirely by and for women. Plus, relearning the rules of romance from the other side of the gender line. And Sarah Vowell tells the story of the Greatest Romance of the 20th Century. Transcript

item.title: 246: My Pen Pal | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of very unusual pen pals, including a ten-year-old girl from Michigan who befriends Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. A show from 2003 that we’re bringing back with news this week of Noriega’s death. Transcript

item.title: 245: Allure of the Mean Friend | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description What is it about them, our mean friends? They treat us badly, they don’t call us back, they cancel plans at the last minute, and yet we come back for more. Popular bullies exist in business, politics, everywhere. How do they stay so popular? Transcript

item.title: 244: MacGyver | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In real life, we usually never get to invent ingenious solutions, like the guy in the old TV series MacGyver. Today, four real stories in which real people invent amazingly clever solutions to their problems. Transcript

item.title: 243: Later That Same Day | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about what the passage of time can do to someone. When each story starts, the world’s aligned one way. Years pass—or sometimes just months—and everything’s different. Transcript

item.title: 242: Enemy Camp | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Living behind enemy lines among the enemy, it’s sometimes hard to remember why you’re fighting in the first place. Transcript

item.title: 241: 20 Acts in 60 Minutes | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Instead of the usual “each week we choose a theme, and bring you 3 or 4 stories on that theme” business, we throw all that away and bring you 20 stories—yes, 20—in 60 minutes. Transcript

item.title: 240: I’m In Charge Now | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people putting themselves in charge in very unlikely, unpromising circumstances. Transcript

item.title: 239: Lost in America | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who are lost, histories that are lost, and things that are lost. This show was recorded onstage in front of audiences on a five-city tour in May 2003. The cities: Boston, Washington DC, Portland Oregon, Denver and Chicago. Featuring house band OK Go. Transcript

item.title: 238: Lost in Translation | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of what can and cannot be translated. A short, non-athletic, bespectacled East Asian studies major who couldn’t make his high school basketball team finds himself in the NBA as the personal translator for the first-ever Chinese pro basketball superstar, Yao Ming. Plus, a Palestinian man teaches Hebrew classes in the Gaza strip to Palestinians eager to learn news from the other side of the checkpoint. Transcript

item.title: 237: Regime Change | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Sure, John Kerry got in trouble for using the phrase, but we have no fear. Because we know that regime change, like charity, begins at home. This week: Stories of regime change in everyday life—people switching jobs, people switching families, businesses dying and new ones starting in their place. Transcript

item.title: 236: My Two Cents | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories from a contradictory recession. Transcript

item.title: 235: The Balloon Goes Up | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories from the beginnings of the war in Iraq, and how it compares with wars in our country’s past. Transcript

item.title: 234: Say Anything | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Does talking about it really help? Stories where it does, and stories where it doesn’t, including a man who tried to battle his fears by listing them. He ended up with a list 138 items long. Transcript

item.title: 233: Starting From Scratch | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description People starting over—sometimes because they want to, other times because they have to. Transcript

item.title: 232: The Real Story | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description It’s been said that truth is the first casualty of war. In this week’s show, we try to get the real stories from three very different wars. Transcript

item.title: 231: Time to Save the World | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people trying to save the world one person at a time, and stories of sudden truths delivered by complete strangers. Transcript

item.title: 230: Come Back to Afghanistan | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In January 2002, the President of Afghanistan, Hamid Karzai, spoke at Georgetown University. There he urged Afghan-Americans, especially young ones, to move back to Afghanistan. Transcript

item.title: 229: Secret Government | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of some of the secrets our government keeps: of imprisonment, deportation, and spying, and how those secrets affect us. Transcript

item.title: 228: You Are So Beautiful…To Me | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Two stories about love, and what people mean when they use the word love. Or, looked at differently, two modern-day reinterpretations of the Frog Prince story. One concerns a pretty man falling in love with an unlikely woman. And an unlikely woman falling in love with a pretty bird. Transcript

item.title: 227: Why We Fight | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about why we should go to war versus stories of why we shouldn’t. Transcript

item.title: 226: Reruns | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people stuck in their own personal reruns—moments or episodes that they revisit over and over again. Transcript

item.title: 225: Home Movies | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Home movies are often all the same—kids on the beach, people getting married, birthday parties—so why do we make and watch so many of them? Maybe it’s because the story they show and the story they tell are different. In this show, we bring you five stories that all start with a fairly typical home movie but go on to tell a unique story. Transcript

item.title: 224: Middlemen | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In this week’s show, we celebrate the oft-beleaguered and misrepresented middleman. “Cut out the middleman! Death to the middleman!” the angry hordes cry. Not us. We say, “Hi, middleman. Here are three splendid acts to toast your subtle virtues.” Transcript

item.title: 223: Classifieds | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In this show we take the classifieds from one Sunday edition of the Chicago Sun-Times and one edition of the local alternative weekly Chicago Reader, and fill a program with stories that come from the ads. Through the jobs offered, the missed connections, the crap that people sell each other and the musicians’ ads we get a portrait of a whole city. Transcript

item.title: 222: Suckers | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Some people have a rather dark worldview that divides people into two groups: Suckers and non-suckers. We hear their stories. Transcript

item.title: 221: Fake I.D. | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people traveling under fake papers, false identities, not for power or personal gain, but for their own deeper personal reasons. Transcript

item.title: 220: Testosterone | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people getting more testosterone and coming to regret it. And of people losing it and coming to appreciate life without it. The pros and cons of the hormone of desire. And we get our testosterone measured, as a staff. Transcript

item.title: 219: High Speed Chase | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of innocent people fleeing from dangerous men in cars who shoot at them. Unlike in the movies, the pursuers aren’t foreign agents or rogue CIA agents, but drunk off-duty policemen and small-town teenagers. Real-ife high-speed chases: who gets chased…and who does the chasing. Transcript

item.title: 218: Act V | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A group of inmates at a high-security prison rehearse and stage a production of the last act—Act V—of Hamlet. Transcript

item.title: 217: Give It to Them | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description It’s been two years since the Mideast peace process collapsed, two years in which each side has done terrible things to the other side. We wanted to understand what that has done to people living in Israel and the West Bank, and to see if anyone is feeling hope. Transcript

item.title: 216: Give the People What They Want | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who go to great lengths to give people what they want, and how they’re rewarded sometimes, misguided other times. Transcript

item.title: 215: Ask An Expert | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people who turned to the experts and got horrible advice. One story is about people who went to therapists who made them sicker. Another is about how the hosts of Car Talk inadvertently (or perhaps intentionally) destroyed a car belonging to one of their own employees. Transcript

item.title: 214: Family Physics | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We take the stately laws of physics—laws which mathematicians and scientists have spent centuries discovering and verifying—and apply them to the realm of human relationships, to see if they shed useful light on our daily lives. Transcript

item.title: 213: Devil on My Shoulder | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who are trying to convince you that the Devil is there, whispering in your ear…and stories of people who try to deny he’s there, against some very heavy evidence. Transcript

item.title: 212: The Other Man | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about what happens when a new guy comes on the scene, and changes the way everyone who was already there relates to each other. Transcript

item.title: 211: Naming Names | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about what happens when you name names. When you turn someone over to the authorities, it can set into motion lots of huge, unintended consequences. A reporter turns over an interviewee to the FBI. A group of teachers turn in their principal. A director turns in his Communist colleagues to the United States Congress. Transcript

item.title: 210: Perfect Evidence | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description After a decade in which DNA evidence has freed over 100 people nationwide, it’s become clear that DNA evidence isn’t just proving wrongdoing by criminals, it’s proving wrongdoing by police and prosecutors. In this show, we look at what DNA has revealed to us: how police get innocent people to confess to crimes they didn’t commit and how they get witnesses to pin crimes on innocent people. Transcript

item.title: 209: Didn’t Ask to Be Born | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Two stories that are worst case scenarios for any parent. In each story, when you take apart what happened and how it happened, it’s hard to see how anyone could’ve prevented things from going bad. Transcript

item.title: 208: Office Politics | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of high drama from our nation’s workplaces. They turn out to be surprising, emotional places, with all the greed, jealousy, and ambition of real politics. Transcript

item.title: 207: Special Ed | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about people who were told that they’re different. Some of them were comfortable with it. Some didn’t understand it. And some understood, but didn’t like it. Transcript

item.title: 206: Somewhere in the Arabian Sea | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Life aboard the USS John C. Stennis, an aircraft carrier that was stationed in the Arabian Sea and supported bombing missions over Afghanistan. Only a few dozen people on board actually fly jets. It takes the rest of the crew — over 5,000 people — to keep them in the air. This American Life producers visited the Stennis in 2002, about six weeks into its deployment. The hour is devoted to this one story.

item.title: 205: Plan B | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description There’s the thing you plan to do, and then there’s the thing you end up doing. Most of us start off our lives with some Plan A, which we abandon…switching to a Plan B, which becomes our life. Transcript

item.title: 204: 81 Words | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The story of how the American Psychiatric Association decided in 1973 that homosexuality was no longer a mental illness. Transcript

item.title: 203: Recordings for Someone | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Personal recordings one person made for just one other person, including what some have called the greatest phone message ever. Transcript

item.title: 202: Faith | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of faith: losing it, talking about it, constructing it, and working within it. Transcript

item.title: 201: Them | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In a time of war, when we’re all feeling a heightened sense of “us” and “them,” we wanted to take up the problem of “them.” Some people need a good “them.” Other people tend to see all “thems” as more like us. And so we bring you three stories of people misperceiving the them-miness of them. Transcript

item.title: 200: Hearts and Minds | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Of all the wars to win, perhaps the propaganda war is the hardest. In this show, we bring you stories of propaganda wars past and present, by those who fought them and those who survived them. Transcript

item.title: 199: House on Loon Lake | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The true story of an abandoned house, discovered by a young boy in the 1970s, and the mysterious family who disappeared without a trace. Transcript

item.title: 198: How to Win Friends and Influence People | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people climbing to be number one. How do they do it? What is the fundamental difference between us and them? Transcript

item.title: 197: Before It Had A Name | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description There’s the time when you know something is happening, but you’re not sure exactly what. The illness before it’s diagnosed. The era, before it’s been given a title. And something changes when the name is given. Stories of that transformation…between what it is now, and what it was before it had a name. Transcript

item.title: 196: Rashomon | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In the movie Rashomon, one story is told from four different points of view. The story changes dramatically depending on who’s telling it. This week, the events of September 11th, and how their meaning changes depending on who you talk to. Transcript

item.title: 195: War Stories | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In September 2001, we tried to sort out what the war in Afghanistan would be like, and what our lives would be like during this war. Transcript

item.title: 194: Before and After | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories in the wake of the events of September 11, 2001. Transcript

item.title: 193: Stories of Loss | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In the wake of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, a collection of stories in which people try to make sense of loss. Transcript

item.title: 192: Meet the Pros | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The story of one man’s journey from obscurity to international professional celebrity—aided only by his own hard work, a sneaker commercial, and mad handles. And other stories of amateurs hurtling themselves at the pros whose jobs they covet. Transcript

item.title: 191: I Know What You Did This Summer | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories for the stultifying, torpor-inducing, hottest heat of summer. Transcript

item.title: 190: Living the Dream | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description There’s a deep impulse in American culture that says that you can make yourself into anyone. Today, three stories about people who tried to do just that. Transcript

item.title: 189: Hitler’s Yacht | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Nearly this entire show is devoted to the story of the boat known as “Hitler’s Yacht.” It’s a modern-day fable about what happens when the free market, the media, the World War II buffs, the Neo-Nazis, and the Jews all collide over a huge Nazi tourist trap. The boat arrived in America after World War II, and though there’s no evidence that Hitler ever set foot on the decks, the name was attached to the vessel in the 1950s, and it stuck.

item.title: 188: Kid Logic (2001) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of kids using perfectly logical arguments, and arriving at perfectly wrong conclusions. Transcript

item.title: 187: Father's Day '01 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For Father’s Day, stories of dads who are utterly human in scale. Transcript

item.title: 186: Prom | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description While the seniors danced at Prom Night 2001 in Hoisington, Kansas—a town of about 3,000—a tornado hit the town, destroying about a third of it. When they emerged from the dance, they discovered what had happened, and in the weeks that followed, they tried to explain to themselves why the tornado hit where it did. Plus other stories that happen on Prom Night. Transcript

item.title: 185: Golden Calf | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people worshiping false idols, and whether that’s always a bad thing. Transcript

item.title: 184: Neighbors | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people trying to love their neighbors, and failing. Transcript

item.title: 183: The Missing Parents Bureau | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about the legacy of absent parents. We hear four cases from the files of the Missing Parents Bureau. Transcript

item.title: 182: Cringe | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories that make us cringe, and an investigation into just what, exactly, makes some stories capable of forcing this physical reaction out of us when other stories don’t. We hear tales of personal humiliation, romance gone wrong, and people who profoundly misjudge how they’re perceived by others. Transcript

item.title: 181: The Friendly Man | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A special show, composed entirely of stories from just one This American Life contributor: Scott Carrier, whose strange and compelling stories sound like nothing else on the radio. Transcript

item.title: 180: Return to Childhood 2001 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who try to revisit their childhoods. What they find. And what they do not find. Transcript

item.title: 179: Cicero | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The story in a way of a town that time forgot, or more accurately, a town that tried to forget the times. A special broadcast co-hosted by award-winning journalist Alex Kotlowitz, author of the books There Are No Children Here and The Other Side of the River. Transcript

item.title: 178: Superpowers | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We answer the following questions about superpowers: Can superheroes be real people? (No.) Can real people become superheroes? (Maybe.) And which is better: flight or invisibility? (Depends who you ask.) Transcript

item.title: 177: American Limbo | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people living completely outside the grid of American life. Americans in Paris. Chinese in America. West Virginians in treehouses. Mexican-Americans in Rochester. Transcript

item.title: 176: Two Nations, One President | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In the wake of the 2001 election debacle in Florida, the two political halves of this country seemed angrier at each other than they had in decades. This week we bring you tales of that widening rift. Democrats explain why they’re having trouble getting over it, and Republicans explain why this is so infuriating. Transcript

item.title: 175: Babysitting | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description What goes on while mom and dad are away, that mom and dad never find out about. Including the story of two teenagers who decide to invent children to babysit, as an excuse to get out of their own house. Transcript

item.title: 174: Birthdays, Anniversaries, and Milestones | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description They mean something, whether we want them to or not. Transcript

item.title: 173: Three Kinds of Deception | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A story of self-deception, a story about deceiving others, and a story about accidental deception. And how one type of deception can easily turn into another. Transcript

item.title: 172: 24 Hours at the Golden Apple | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We document one day in a Chicago diner called the Golden Apple, starting at 5 a.m. and going until 5 a.m. the next morning. We hear from the waitress who has worked the graveyard shift for over two decades, the regular customers who come every day, the couples working out their problems, assorted drunks, and, of course, cops. Transcript

item.title: 171: Election | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories for the eve of the Presidential election, in which we try to evade, sidestep or look beneath the candidates’ soundbites. Transcript

item.title: 170: Immigration | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We live in a big enough country that there are lots of laws too obscure for most of us to have heard of…but which actually affect tens of thousands of lives in huge ways. This show deals with one of them: A 1996 immigration law that the Immigration Service itself says is unfair. Most of the law’s original sponsors in Congress now say they went too far, and that they were too harsh when they passed the law.

item.title: 169: Pursuit of Happiness | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We as a nation declared our independence based on, among other things, the right to pursue our happiness. But what does it mean, over two centuries later, to grow up in a country with an inalienable right to pursue happiness? Stories of people pursuing happiness, and sometimes, achieving it. Transcript

item.title: 168: The Fix Is In | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description There are all sorts of situations in which we suspect the fix is in, but we almost never find out for certain. On today’s show, for once, we find out. The whole program is devoted to one story, in which we go inside the back rooms of one multinational corporation and hear the intricate workings—recorded on tape—of how they put the fix in. Transcript

item.title: 167: Memo to the People of the Future | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who are engaged in something that’s both difficult and probably futile: Trying to control how they’ll be seen by generations to come. Transcript

item.title: 166: Nobody's Family Is Going to Change | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Three stories that consider the question: Does anyone’s family ever change? Transcript

item.title: 165: Americans in Paris | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Many Americans have dreamy and romantic ideas about Paris, notions which probably trace back to the 1920s vision of Paris created by the expatriate Americans there. But what’s it actually like in Paris if you’re an American, without rose-colored glasses? Transcript

item.title: 164: Crime Scene | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Every crime scene hides a story. In this week’s show, we hear about crime scenes and the stories they tell. Transcript

item.title: 163: Can You Fight City Hall…If You Are City Hall? | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of a typically American kind of hero: The person who decides to fight city hall, who stands up alone for what’s right, and damn the consequences. We hear the story of two idealists who work in government, two centuries after another set of idealists created the American government. Both of the modern idealists suffer and sacrifice because of their ideals; both lose their jobs. Transcript

item.title: 162: Moving | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who did not want to move but circumstance forced their hands, and so they tried to move without really moving. Transcript

item.title: 161: Million Bubbles | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Imagine that you could somehow look down from above, onto all the streets and avenues and country roads and highways of this nation…each car below its own tiny subculture on wheels…glass and steel worlds rolling down the street alongside each other. We hear what’s going on inside some of these cars. Transcript

item.title: 160: Character Assassination | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In context of the Presidential contest between George W. Bush and Al Gore, we hear stories of character assassination—political and non-political. Transcript

item.title: 159: Mother’s Day | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of moms: How they treat us, how we treat them. Transcript

item.title: 158: Mob Mentality | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The pleasure of being in a rampaging, angry mob…and the terror of being in a rampaging, angry mob. Transcript

item.title: 157: Secret Life of Daytime | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description All those people you see in the middle of the workday, in coffee shops and bookstores? Who are they? Why aren’t they at work? Transcript

item.title: 156: What Remains | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Usually This American Life brings you stories of people in the middle of big experiences. But sometimes these moments of dramatic change are only half the story. The other half occurs after time passes and they return to revisit what happened, and who they were back when. Today’s show is about what they find. Transcript

item.title: 155: Hoaxing Yourself (2000) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who tell a lie and then believe the lie more than anyone else does. In other words: Stories about people pulling hoaxes…on themselves. Transcript

item.title: 154: In Dog We Trust (2000) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of dogs and cats and other animals that live in our homes. Exactly how much are they caught up in everyday family dynamics? We answer this question and others. Transcript

item.title: 153: Dolls | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of what people are playing at when they play with dolls. Transcript

item.title: 152: Crush | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of love in its earliest stage. Crushes: what’s terrible about them, what’s great about them and how they can overshadow real love for some people. Transcript

item.title: 151: Primary | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Today’s program is made all of stories from the New Hampshire primary. Voters want to find a candidate who inspires them. Candidates want to inspire. So where’s the system failing? Why do most of us feel like the system doesn’t produce anyone inspiring? We hear stories that answer why. We hear from voters who’ve found candidates they love. And we hear what those voters are seeing that the rest of us aren’t.

item.title: 150: Kids As Adults | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of kids trying to act like adults—some by choice—some because they’re forced to. Transcript

item.title: 149: Bedside Diplomacy | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description In the hospital, we give up our normal schedule and sleep patterns; we give up our normal food and clothing; we’re in a place that has its own rules and its own language and its own customs. And in the midst of all this, there’s this complicated human interaction we have to negotiate: We have to deal with doctors and nurses to get the care we need. In this show we hear stories of those delicate and sometimes not-so-delicate negotiations.

item.title: 148: The Angels Wanna Wear My Red Suit | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A special Christmas edition of our show, with stories about Santa Claus—me It was in America, in New York, that people started believing in the modern idea of Santa—a guy who comes down the chimney with a sack of goodies. But America has invented a few other Santas as well. Transcript

item.title: 147: A Teenager's Guide to God | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description It’s an odd fact of religious life in America that in this country founded by Christians, in which a majority of people say they believe in God and identify themselves as Christians, that so many religious Christians feel they’re an oppressed minority. They say the media doesn’t share their values. That secular institutions undermine their beliefs. And the job of raising Christian children, they’ll tell you, is like trying to do God’s work from behind enemy lines.

item.title: 146: Urban Nature | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of nature creeping into man-made environments. Of nature sneaking in places where its very presence is a rebuke to the notion that we as a species have things under control. Transcript

item.title: 145: Poultry Slam 1999 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For Thanksgiving, the time of year when poultry consumption is highest, it’s our annual program about turkeys, chickens, fowl of all types, and their mysterious hold over our imaginations. This show includes favorite stories from previous Poultry Shows, and some new stories. Transcript

item.title: 144: Where Words Fail | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description One reason we tell stories is to explain things to ourselves that cannot, in the end, always be explained. When someone we’re close to dies, we struggle for a way to get our minds around the fact of their absence. And often—the stories we invent aren’t quite up to the job. In this week’s show, people struggle to invent words adequate to cope with death. Transcript

item.title: 143: Sentencing | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We’ve all heard occasional news stories about how some of the drug laws enacted in the last 15 years may have gone too far. First time offenders get locked up for decades. Judges—even Republican appointees—say that mandatory minimum sentences prevent them from making fair rulings. But have sentences really gone too far? This hour examines the areas where a consensus is growing on the problems in federal drug laws, and it explains the areas where drug laws seem to be administered fairly.

item.title: 142: Barbara | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We hear the story of one African-American single mother. Barbara Clinkscales recorded her family’s life over the course of seven months for This American Life. Her life defies—or makes irrelevant—most of our typical notions of inner-city, black single mothers. Transcript

item.title: 141: Invisible Worlds | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who are trying to make invisible worlds visible, and what happens when you make them visible. Transcript

item.title: 140: Family Business | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of family businesses, and what happens when the tension of family dynamics collides with the pressure of capitalist market forces. Transcript

item.title: 139: Ghosts of Elections Past | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of political idealists, stories designed to provide some small sense of hope about American politics. Most of these were first broadcast during the 1996 Presidential race. Transcript

item.title: 138: The Real Thing | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people drawn to some idea, some picture, some “thing” that they just want to be. How some people imitate this “thing” innocently, some less innocently, and how easy it is to slip from one to the other. Transcript

item.title: 137: The Book That Changed Your Life | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who believe a book changed their life. It’s a romantic notion, and one reason we believe it is because we want to believe our lives can be changed by something so simple as an idea — or a set of ideas contained in a book. Transcript

item.title: 136: You Are Here | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Three stories, three people, and three sets of maps. Stories of people trying to figure out where they are in the world in the most literal and least literal ways possible. We explore what it’s like to be lost—how we all struggle in that moment not to give ourselves over to fear but try to enjoy it. Transcript

item.title: 135: Allure of Crime | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description We think of crime as a kind of monolithic, menacing presence. But there are many kinds of crimes and many kinds of criminals. Through our crimes, we express who we are. Today we hear of three different criminals and three different kinds of crimes. Transcript

item.title: 134: We Didn’t | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about what happens when we don’t do something. It turns out that not falling in love, not doing our jobs, not spending time with our families is every bit as vivid and complicated an experience as doing something. Transcript

item.title: 133: Sales | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Consider for a moment all the art forms that began in America: jazz, the blues, musical theater, rock n’ roll, phonograph recordings, television, motion pictures, video games. But the art form in which America leads the world—more than any other—is the art of selling. In this show: case examples to prove the point. Transcript

item.title: 132: Father’s Day ‘99 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For Father’s Day, stories about fathers going out of their way to protect their kids, and kids going out of their way to protect their fathers. Transcript

item.title: 131: The Kids Are Alright | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories in which young people take matters into their own hands: Students who become political activists, students who pull pranks, violent students. Broadcast for the tenth anniversary of the crackdown at Tiananmen Square. Transcript

item.title: 130: Away From Home | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people going home to places they’ve never been before. Transcript

item.title: 129: Advice | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description A program taped before live audiences in Seattle (thanks to public radio station KUOW) and at HBO’s U.S. Comedy Arts Festival in Aspen. A taxonomy of different kinds of advice—and stories that illustrate why advice is so rarely taken. Transcript

item.title: 128: Four Corners | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description There’s a tourist monument called Four Corners, where Arizona, Colorado, Utah and New Mexico meet. In this episode, we try to tell the story of life in America through portraits of life on four different corners, in four different states across the nation. Transcript

item.title: 127: Pimp Anthropology | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description This entire show is devoted to just one story. A former pimp tells how he and three childhood friends became pimps in the 1970s in Oakland, California. He explains all the elaborate “rules of the game” among pimps and prostitutes of that era. He didn’t have the stomach for the violence of pimping, and failed as a pimp because of that. Tamar Brott reports. Transcript

item.title: 126: Do-Gooders | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people trying to do good: Why they often fail and why they occasionally succeed. Transcript

item.title: 125: Apocalypse | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of the end of the world. More people believe it’s more imminent than you probably realize. Transcript

item.title: 124: Welcome to America | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people moving to this country: what they see and hear about America that those of us who were born here don’t necessarily see. Transcript

item.title: 123: High Cost of Living | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people who choose not to live every moment to the fullest or smell the roses, and instead choose to withdraw from life, to make themselves numb. Transcript

item.title: 122: Valentine’s Day ’99 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For Valentine’s Day, stories of impossible love and heartbreak. Transcript

item.title: 121: Twentieth Century Man | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description One thing that makes our country different from most others is this idea that you can re-create yourself as someone you’d prefer to be…sell everything off, head out west, start a new life. But what happens if you’re too good at it? At throwing everything out and starting over? Transcript

item.title: 120: Be Careful Who You Pretend to Be | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Three stories of people pretending to be something they’re not, and what happens to them. Transcript

item.title: 119: Lockup | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description With the number of prisoners in the United States rising rapidly, we present stories of their lives and the lives of their families and children. Transcript

item.title: 118: What You Lookin’ At? | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about seeing and being seen. Taped before a live audience in Town Hall in New York City in December 1998, this was a co-production with WNYC New York, featuring live music by the pop band They Might Be Giants and the This American Life Orchestra. Transcript

item.title: 117: You Gonna Eat That? | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The family table is stage on which many family dramas are played out. We hear three stories, of three families, at three meals. Transcript

item.title: 116: Poultry Slam 1998 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For Thanksgiving, the time of year when poultry consumption is highest, it’s our annual program about turkeys, chickens, and fowl of all types. Transcript

item.title: 115: First Day | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of the first day on the job, the first day in a relationship, the first day in school. On the first day, any first day, we’re expected to live by the rules and customs of the culture we’re entering, but we don’t know those rules and customs just yet. These are stories of people trying to make the transition—and the difficulty of making the transition—in a new place, from outsider to insider.

item.title: 114: Last Words | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories of people’s last words before death. Their one last shot at figuring things out, summing things up. One last moment of asserting the fact of our existence, at the moment of our annihilation. Transcript

item.title: 113: Windfall | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description What happens when you suddenly strike it rich. And the power money has over our lives, for good and bad. Transcript

item.title: 112: Ladies and Germs | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Germs, and how they make us leave the world of rational thinking. Transcript

item.title: 111: Adventures in the Simple Life | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description I thought this was supposed to be easy. Tales from the simple life. Transcript

item.title: 110: Mapping | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Five ways of mapping the world. One story about people who make maps the traditional way — by drawing things we can see. And other stories about people who map the world using smell, sound, touch, and taste. The world redrawn by the five senses. Transcript

item.title: 109: Notes on Camp | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description People who love summer camp say that non-camp people simply don’t understand what’s so amazing about it. We attempt to bridge this gap of misunderstanding between camp people and non-camp people. Transcript

item.title: 108: Truth and Lies at Age Ten | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Two stories of children lying to themselves and others. A woman who’d been diagnosed with cystic fibrosis talks about the lies she told herself as a child. And Dan Gediman tells the story of how he was cast in the public TV show Zoom, which aired from 1972 to 1979, at the age of ten. Then he was cut from the cast before the show ever went on the air.

item.title: 107: Trail of Tears (1998) | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Writer Sarah Vowell and her twin sister re-trace the “Trail of Tears” — the route their Cherokee ancestors took when expelled from their own land by President Andrew Jackson. On the way, Sarah and her sister visit the land they would have grown up in had the Cherokees not been expelled, Andrew Jackson’s home, and the land in Oklahoma where the Cherokee nation settled (and where Sarah and her sister were born).

item.title: 106: Father’s Day ‘98 | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For this Father’s Day, stories in which fathers and their kids sit down and try to have an honest moment together. And stories about fathers who aren’t close with their kids. Transcript

item.title: 105: Take A Negro Home | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Two stories of people who try to cross the color line — and why it’s still so hard. We hear the story of a failed interracial marriage and the story of a teenager from a poor inner city neighborhood (Cedric Jennings, pictured) who ends up at an Ivy League University — and how he barely survives there. Transcript

item.title: 104: Music Lessons | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description What’s frustrating about music lessons, what’s miraculous about them, and what they actually teach us. This show was recorded in front of a live audience at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco, with help from KQED-FM, during the 1998 Public Radio Conference in San Francisco. Transcript

item.title: 103: Scenes from A Transplant | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description An NPR reporter leaves her three-year-old son and heads to Omaha—for cancer treatment—a last chance to save her life. After years of covering stories about medicine, Rebecca Perl enters the hospital as a patient. She moves from the world of healthy people into the world of sick ones. What she sees and what she learns. Transcript

item.title: 102: Road Trip! | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description With so many songs, movies, and books about the joy of the open road, it’s hard to take just a normal road trip without huge expectations. Transcript

item.title: 101: Niagara | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description The story of Niagara Falls, a town that started with something huge—the falls—and built nothing lasting from it. During this hour, a special edition of our show: Stories about Niagara Falls, half of them from documentary producer Alix Spiegel, who went to the Falls and interviewed people living there; and half from playwright David Kodeski, who grew up in the town of Niagara Falls. Transcript

item.title: 100: Radio | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description For the 100th episode of This American Life, a radio show about the pleasures of radio. About what makes radio so great, and what makes it so terrible. Transcript

item.title: 99: I Enjoy Being A Girl, Sort Of | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Variations on what it means to be a girl and what it means to be a woman. Transcript

item.title: 98: Throwing the First Punch | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description Stories about what it means to be a person who throws the first punch, and how hard it is to give up. Transcript

item.title: 97: Death to Wacky | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description An assault on the idea of wackiness. And then, an appreciation of wackiness, and an analysis of wackiness in American culture. Thirteen ways to describe wackiness. Transcript

item.title: 96: Pinned by History | This American Life
item.description: Podcast Description People who left their private lives and were seized by some huge historical moment. Transcript

item.title: 95: Monogamy | This American Life
